definition.def: XQuery support is progressing fast: I have put up a few XQuery examples to demonstrate some of the new features available in the current development version. XQuery support is still far from being complete, but you can already do a lot of fascinating things.

0.9.2 is out! This is the first official release with support for XUpdate. Also, much effort has been invested to ensure that East Asian character encodings are correctly processed by the database as well as the query engine. Further changes include: important missing parts of the XPath spec have been implemented, more synchronization and database corruption bugs have been fixed and interfaces improved.

section.title: Overview
section.p: eXist is an Open Source native XML database featuring efficient, index-based XQuery processing, extensions for full-text search, XUpdate support and tight integration with existing XML development tools. To avoid memory-intensive document tree traversals during query processing, eXist uses an efficient index structure which is based on a numerical indexing scheme for identifying XML nodes in the index. The database is lightweight, completely written in Java and may be easily deployed in a number of ways, running either as a stand-alone server process, inside a servlet-engine or directly embedded into an application.

Beginning with version 1.0, entire web-based applications can be written with just XQuery and XSLT. XQuery is not only used as a query language, but to implement the whole processing logic of the web application. eXist provides several extension modules for the required tasks.

The XQuery engine is a complete rewrite and replaces the old XPath engine. It implements the current XQuery working draft as of November, 2003 with the exception of the XML schema related features. Extensions to XPath/XQuery are provided to efficiently support document-centric queries, which overcome the inability of the standard function library to produce satisfactory results when querying larger sections of text.
For a summary of eXist's features please have a look at the feature sheet.

section.title: Download
section.p: eXist is released to the public under the terms of the GNU LGPL license.

eXist may be downloaded either as a package containing the complete distribution or as a web application archive (war-file). Download the war-file if you want to install eXist into an existing servlet-engine or write your own web application. To get started, we suggest downloading the installer or the zip package. Both contain a ready-to-run webserver (Jetty).
The distribution includes source code and all required third party libraries. The current version is 1.0beta1. For instructions on starting eXist, read the Quick Start Guide.

We started to release frequent development snapshots. The snapshots reflect the current state of development. You can find them in the unstable package on the Sourceforge file release system.

section.title: Mailing list
section.p: There's a mailing list on sourceforge. If you are interested in using or contributing to eXist, you are encouraged to join the list.
The list is archived at Gmane.

section.title: Articles
section.p: If you would like to know more about the internal workings of eXist, you may read the following article:

Wolfgang Meier. eXist: An Open Source Native XML Database. In: Akmal B. Chaudri, Mario Jeckle, Erhard Rahm, Rainer Unland (Eds.): Web, Web-Services, and Database Systems. NODe 2002 Web- and Database-Related Workshops, Erfurt, Germany, October 2002. Springer LNCS Series, 2593.
A chapter about eXist is also contained in the book:
Akmal B. Chaudri, Awais Rashid, Roberto Zicari (Eds.): XML Data Management: Native XML and XML-Enabled Database Systems. ISBN: 0-201-84452-4. Published by Addison Wesley Professional, March, 2003.
